block.p: Strained Talks in Paris On Mideast Violence Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, struggled to reach an agreement on how to stop the violence that has torn through Israel and the Palestinian territories.
The number of dead since Friday climbed to at least 65, all but 3 of them Palestinians.

The number of dead since Friday climbed to at least 65, all but 3 of them Palestinians.

Strikers Face Down Serb Police Strikers at a Serbian mine refused police orders to halt their protest against the rule of President Slobodan Milosevic, and instead called for help. Some 20,000 people poured into the mine to defend the workers, and the police broke and stood aside.
Yugoslavia's high court annulled parts of the Sept. 24 election.

Suharto Son Denied Pardon President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia refused to pardon Hutomo Mandala Putra, the former dictator Suharto's son who was convicted and sentenced to jail in a land scheme. The president also ordered a notorious militia leader arrested.
Mexico Deports Cuban Official Pedro Riera Escalante, a longtime Cuban intelligence official who had broken with his government and sought refuge in Mexico, was arrested and deported to Cuba.

Limits Sought on Abortion Pill Republicans in the House and the Senate introduced legislation that would require special qualifications for doctors who prescribe the newly approved abortion pill RU-486.
RU-486 accounts for about 30 percent of all abortions in France, but far from promoting abortion, the pill seems to have had little effect on the number performed each year.

Reprieve for Laser Project Congress nearly tripled the original budget for the 2001 fiscal year for a multibillion-dollar laser project at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory that proponents had feared might be shut because of cost overruns and construction delays.

Both Sides Say Debate Probably Changed Little Republicans and Democrats alike conceded that the overall dynamics of the presidential race did not seem to have been changed by the debate between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. Top officials on both sides said their candidates had met their basic objectives during the televised encounter, which was watched by 46 million people.
Mr. Gore asserted that his vision of using the American military to build new democracies after peace is won is rooted in the Marshall Plan.
Gore aides accused Mr. Bush of making several misstatements in the debate while admitting that Mr. Gore had made some slips himself.
Mr. Bush accused Mr. Gore of being ''the biggest spender we've seen in decades'' and defended his own $1.3 trillion tax cut proposal.
Ralph Nader threatened a civil rights lawsuit over his being barred from the debate audience.

Equal-Time Rules Relaxed The government suspended rules requiring radio and television stations to provide free reply time for opponents of political candidates endorsed by the stations, and for candidates and others whose integrity is attacked. The F.C.C. said it wanted to encourage robust political debate.

McCain Promotes Gun Issues Senator John McCain is appearing in television commercials promoting ballot initiatives in Colorado and Oregon that would require people who buy firearms at gun shows to undergo criminal background checks.

Abuse Inquiry at I.N.S. Center The Justice Department is investigating complaints from women held at the Krome immigration detention center near Miami who said they had witnessed or were victims of sexual assaults by federal guards.
Maternity, Drugs and Privacy The Supreme Court heard arguments on a South Carolina hospital's drug testing of maternity patients and its turning over of positive results to the police.
The Justices heard arguments on restrictions that Congress placed on Legal Services lawyers representing welfare clients.

U.S. Finds Police Profiling; City Pressed for Remedy Federal prosecutors in Manhattan determined that the New York Police Department's Street Crime Unit engaged in racial profiling as its officers conducted a campaign of street searches. Prosecutors are discussing the findings with the Giuliani administration in pursuit of changes that could avert a lawsuit.

Warning on Subway Safety The M.T.A.'s inspector general said several subway lines were ''potentially in danger of experiencing a train collision, derailment or serious delays'' because supervisors had failed to make hundreds of inspections of signal equipment.
Harassment Process Faulted New procedures to handle sexual harassment complaints at Columbia drew criticism from some groups and civil liberties lawyers.
Incentive Program Results Two-thirds of California's public schools showed improvement in the first year of a program that ties academic performance to financial rewards for schools and educators.

Plea Deal in Auctions Case Diana D. Brooks, former president and chief executive of Sotheby's, was said to have agreed to plead guilty to conspiring to violate antitrust laws with the auction house's archrival, Christie's. The deal would make Ms. Brooks a witness against her longtime boss, Sotheby's former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman.
Large Gift to Library The billionaire investor and philanthropist John W. Kluge gave $60 million to the Library of Congress.
Yanks Pull Even in Oakland The Yankees beat the A's, 4-0, in Game 2 of their playoff series. The Mets lost their opener to the Giants, 5-1. Seattle beat Chicago, 5-2.

U.S. Taps Oil Reserves The Energy Department sold 30 million barrels of crude from the strategic reserve to 11 companies. News of the sale drove the price for November delivery down 64 cents, or 2 percent, to $31.43 a barrel.
The Bermuda Angle Sentiment is growing on Capitol Hill to close a loophole that lets insurance companies stop paying income taxes by opening an office in Bermuda.
Warning from Dell Computers Dell, one of the personal computer industry's most successful companies, said third-quarter sales would fall short of expectations.
